description: Uncertain; perhaps quiz +‎ -by, or from queer or Queer Street (“difficult circumstances”).

adjectives.description: quisby (comparative more quisby, superlative most quisby)

entries.meaning: (UK, slang, archaic) Mean; destitute; strange. [from 19th c.]
(UK, slang, archaic) In difficult circumstances; in trouble.
examples: [S]he told me as things was a-goin' werry quisby with 'em Wilkses. I says, "I'm sorry for 'er, but he's a party I don't 'old with, as in my opinion deserves to want, only but for others as would want with 'im."She says, "He's been and got 'isself in a 'ole with them books as he've been lewanted with, and will get two years over it, they say," and so he did,  […]
" […]  Did you know that my husband came home intoxicated?"Mrs. Brown laughed."Oh, not so bad as that, surely! Only a little 'screwed.' George was 'quisby,' too. But then its Christmas, you know."

entries.meaning: (slang, obsolete) A wretch; an idle person. [18th–19th c.]
